I joined a gym 2 years ago, to get stronger, build muscle, and just improve overall fitness.  I got a late start, I was never an outdoorsy/exercise type for the first 60 years of my life, but a new relationship inspired me to be so.

Short story, I have gotten more out of two weeks/30 minutes/6 days a week with Leslie than two years with the gym. I sweat every time I work out with her (rarely did with a multiple machine 90 minute gym circuit 3x a week) although I worked hard. No, I did not hire a personal trainer--$30 a a 25 minute session was way out of my budget, especially when you had to commit to a minimum of 4 sessions/mo).

I realized that the gym equipment makes you stronger--for using the gym equipment, not everyday practical strength. I could do 3 sets of 25 reps at 70lbs on the lateral press and 3/25 pull/push 145 on hip ad and abductors, but struggled to lift a 40lb bag of softener salt--what good is that on a day to day basis?

I'm saving $35 and eighteen hours/mo (fee and workout time+commute) and getting a LOT more out of it. I'm stonger, more coordinated and my balance has greatly improved--in just two weeks.

Combining this tape with walking my dogs for an hour+ five days a week (weather permitting) and some additional free weight work, I am happy to FINALLY start accomplishing what I set out to do.

Note:  I discovered Leslie at my library, so have gotten this for free (tried several other instructors as well) but will be buying this and other LS dvds.

Impressed and so happy to have found an easy--and EFFECTIVE--work out regimen.

I have been doing 5 miles of Leslie's DVD's every day for a few years now.  The past year and a half  I mainly stuck to her Miracle Miles, but 3 days a week I started doing 1 of her Walk and Firm miles, and then 4 Miracle Miles. I even ordered a stronger version of the Miracle Miles band because I wasn't sweaty after 5 miles. I was getting bored so I asked my husband to get me the Walk Off in 30 days as a gift. Wow! This is the first time I can remember my muscles were actually challenged. Leslie doesn't count miles in the 30 day walk off, but I'm guessing both workouts together are equivalent to 4 miles, but I was challenged by this workout so I didn't feel the need to do the 5th mile. (You are not supposed to do both workouts in the same day, but since I do 5 miles everyday I figured I'd combine them. However I won't be doing this DVD everyday.  I'll stick to the 3 days I had been doing 1 Firm mile and 4 Miracle Miles) There are also no annoying comments from her cast during either of the workouts. My only complaint is that the workouts keep moving quickly, so I couldn't grab a sip of water as often as I do in her other videos. Otherwise this is one my new favorites!

The idea is to walk it off in 30 days. That was not my intent, I just wanted to tone up and feel better, so I never used the DVD daily as suggested.

As the weeks went by I was able to follow the exercise routine in full, and my legs and tummy area were definitely toning up. A year or two later I decided to join a Taekwondo gym (Because I find it hard to motivate myself to exercise at home and I find it a lot easier to follow a structured class with like minded people, however you will get very fit if you do this DVD daily). Since practicing Taekwondo I have become much fitter, but I still use this DVD. Now I use it as a strong warm up, around 20 minutes, and then I follow up with stretching and some Taekwondo exercises.

I LOVE these workouts! There are two 30 min workouts on the DVD; one is strength training, & the other is strictly cardio. Leslie is her usual upbeat, encouraging self. The recommendation is that you alternate the 2 wrkouts 6 days a each week, taking Sunday (or another day of your choosing) as a 'rest' day. This is the 30 day challenge. I can now proudly say that two days ago, I completed the 30 day challenge. I feel it's very "do-able" but effective. I can see some lean definition in my arms, & tho I didn't take measurements before beginning challenge, I lost the few extra lbs I'd gained on recent vacation, & can definitely tell a reduction in my waistline. In the 30 min strength wrkout, you start out doing about 5 mins of Leslie's usual "walk" moves as warm up, then go right into using hand weights, doing squats & lunges. If you have issues doing squats & lunges, this is probably not the workout for you, lol. You also do bicep curls, & other upper body strengthening repetitions. It ends with about 10 mins on mat doing a few other arm exercises, & ab work. I'm very impressed that so much is covered in just 30 mins. I also like that both wrkouts show an on-screen clock countdown for last 10 mins. These will def be favorite 'go to' workouts for me.

I'm female, 5'7 and about 187 pounds, early 30s, mom of one. The higher calorie burn is from the aerobic workout and lower the strength training portion. I'm not a newbie but not advanced, I would say I'm somewhere above beginner. Keep in mind these calorie burns will vary depending on several factors. Now to my review! I discovered Leslie on YouTube. I needed something easier that day and she offered a nice and steady walk. I enjoyed it. I tried others she had on there and some for me were much too easy. Something I would do again if I needed steps or something to just get moving. I decided to check out Amazon to purchase a DVD (I'm also a huge Jessica Smith fan too and own several of her DVDs) and read reviews on a couple different ones. The reviews on this from fans were saying that this was more challenging than other workouts of hers. I have to agree! Hand weights are used in both. Both are a total body workout and one focuses more on cardio and the other strength training. I hate floor work, and the segment was short on the floor part of strength training and I didn't think it was that bad. Some movements I missed reps because my back and neck muscles aren't very strong but I could still do the movement and will get better as I do it more. It wasn't that crazy, and like I said I'm not a fan of floor work. You can make this more or less intense by getting heavier weights, not using weights etc. The cardio especially flew by, I had a good amount of time in peak HR. I was working hard but enjoying it, not doing super crazy moves , it didn't feel like a workout but I got a great workout. In order to have long term success you need to be able to keep up and want to do your workouts or you won't. I feel both Leslie and even Jessica I mentioned previously offer that. I love walking, kickboxing and barre the most and this had a slight feeling of all especially in the cardio portion of the workout. Plus weights used in both so you're toning and getting more of a workout! I would say that's a win win. Highly recommend this DVD and the price point too is great. I usually jump around with all my DVDs but I'm going to try and do this for a solid month and see what my results are using this combined with weight watchers.

I have been an avid Leslie fan for years but in August of 2016 I decided to really try to lose weight. Through diet moderation and exercising with Leslie at least 3 days a week I have lost 40 pounds and gained a tremendous amount of muscle. My favorite workout of hers is "Walk Strong." In that workout you alternate 3 minutes of fast walking with 3 minutes of weight training for 30 minutes. She makes you do an enormous amount of squats and she throws in a few sets of lunges as well. Walk It Off in 30 Days kicked my butt in the weight portion. There are even more squats than Walk Strong and a ton of lunges, as well as upper body work in the lunge position. I would estimate 10-15 minutes of squats and lunges. By the time I finished my butt and legs were trembling. The squats and lunges have really toned and tightened my butt and thighs. I love them when I have finished them. The next day I could feel the changes and new muscles in my butt hurt. The cardio portion made me sweat right away but was doable and fun. Not a beginner walk video for those new to exercise. Long time Leslie fans will love this video. So glad I got it as I am trying to lose another 40 pounds.

I began August 23rd, 2016, with no energy; could not even use ANY hand weights at first, but finally graduated from nothing to 2.5 pounds each, then 5 each, the 8 each.  I weighed in at 165, 5'6" age 59, size 14 (were tight).  By Thanksgiving 2016, I lost 17 pounds, and for the first time in my life - in a size 10, comfortably.  I was diligent about the 30 day program, then went to alternate days, because I LOVE LOVE LOVE the workout with the weights - the non-walking workout -  until November. I could not believe (still) that I am in a size 10,  and wish I would have measured to know the inches that were lost too.  Don't hesitate. Do your self an favor - DO IT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

The first time I did the "Firm 30", I was sweating, sure, but I didn't realize how bad it kicked my butt until I had to run downstairs for something. For a beginner, I'd definitely recommend one of her easier videos first.  Once you work up to it, however, this will definitely make you stronger and leaner.  (Also, remember Leslie's big thing:  How much you do doesn't matter as much as doing it EVERY DAY.)

I have done some Leslie Sansone workouts throughout the years and while I liked them, I was never crazy about them.  However, this one I like a lot!  I used to be an intermediate exerciser but this past year, a chronic illness has prevented me from doing much of anything.  I really appreciate the simplicity of this workout and how I can feel I accomplished something without killing myself or being over extended.

The "Burn 30" (cardio workout) is definitely faster paced than I'm used to with Leslie and she does add some jogging and bouncing, but it's so easy to modify to your own level and pace that this would be just fine for beginners, or someone recovering from illness like me.  She holds light hand weights during this part too but again, that's optional.  You can make the cardio segment as tough or easy as you'd like.  After a brief warm-up you get into the workout which includes her famous side steps, hamstring curls, kicks, marching/jogging and knees up with a few skaters, cha cha's and bouncing in place added to the mix.  At the end, she does some squats and then there is a short stretch.

The "Firm 30" workout is more for beginners and slower paced, but a good total body workout.  The workout begins with a short warm up of marches, side to side, kicks and knees up and then it's on to squats!  There are lots of squats (wide legged, narrow legged and plies for the inner thighs), as well as lunges.  While Leslie only does a few actual lunges in place, the rest of the workout for the upper body is done in a lunge position.  For example, you will do back rows, tricep kickbacks, bicep curls, overhead presses, etc., all while in lunge position (she switches which leg is in the lunge for each upper body movement).  I actually like this because the whole workout works your lower half but if you have knee issues or just hate lunges, you can always do the upper body stuff standing.  She finishes the standing segment with some more squats and then it's on to the floor with chest presses/flies, abdominal work, bridge work for the backside and a movement for the lower back (I forget the name but you're on your knees for that one).

As I mentioned above, this has been just what I need for my current health needs.  You get a good workout and can still go on and enjoy your day, not feeling beat up but rather, energized!  I only gave it 4 stars because I felt the cool down in the strength workout was less than sufficient considering all the lower body work.  It's less than a minute of just lying on the floor in a full stretched out position.  There's nothing for the legs or any other part of the body.  I understand she had to fit in a lot in 30 minutes, but a few more stretches would have made this perfect.  I just do them on my own.

I really like this DVD. The music is fresh and the moves are challenging. There are two different workouts on the DVD: the walking program, Burn 30, and the strength program, Firm 30. Leslie suggests doing them on alternating days for 30 days. Let's look at both segments:

Burn 30 is a fast-paced walk featuring several boosts, including hops, the cha-cha, and skaters, which really get the heart rate up, as well as a cool-down and quick stretch. One thing this program does not have that I wish it had are mile markers. I'd guess this walk is close to 2.5 miles, but that's just a guess. (This is one reason for my 4-star rating.) I enjoy the workout and it goes by quickly. After twenty minutes, a timer pops up in the corner counting down the last 10 minutes of the workout.

Firm 30 is the toning portion of the workout and calls for the use of  hand weights (I use 3 pounds). This program calls for a lot of lunges and squats, but you can definitely modify - a lot of the lunges are actually done while working the upper body. I injured my ACL a few years ago, so I have to be very careful with my knees, and this workout has not given me any problems at all. But do be aware of the legwork if you have knee trouble. After the legs and arms, there is about 10 minutes of floor work for the abs, obliques, and back end. Firm 30 is a challenging workout, especially if you're new to that type of exercise.

I do this workout a few times a week (about every other day), and I choose to do the entire DVD at once. I am really glad that Leslie has put out a workout like this that includes strength training. That type of exercise can be redundant, unexciting, and even intimidating, but Leslie makes it accessible and energizing. I do miss seeing some of the regular walkers, though, and I really wish there were mile markers. Overall, a great workout!

Let me set the stage here - growing up I wasn't into the one video of Leslie's I had tried (Advanced Walk Aerobics when her last name was Tommelleo) in the early 90's.  I was hooked on the Jane Fonda videos, mainly the earlier and more difficult videos like her first, the New Workout and Workout Challenge.  Jane's format stuck with me and it was nearly impossible to persuade me to try another instructor, aside from a few instances of Tae Bo mixed in.

Fast forward to 2014, at a much higher weight (300+ lbs).  Out of shape and need to get in gear.  I opt for the Walk Away the Pounds 1 and 2 Mile Walks.  A nice pace (not slow but not too fast, enough to get me sweating using the weights).  I liked her.  She was cheery, fun to listen to, and I felt accomplished finishing the video.  She provides mile markers to show your progress and it made me proud to have gotten 2, 3, 4 or 5 miles done in one session when I had aching walking on the street weeks prior just walking a few blocks.  I then grabbed three more of her DVDs, including the Ultimate 5 Day Walk Plan.  This was more energetic and faster-paced - a great program to go with that can be customized to almost any mile/toning combo you like.

Then I tried this one out.  And does it give you a heck of a workout.  The DVD has 2 programs - Burn 30 (aerobics) and Firm 30 (toning and sculpting).  The Burn includes the basic moves you have come to expect from her videos, plus some modified versions of side step and "boosted walking" - jogging, simply.  Leslie and some of the folks behind her use hand/wrist weights for added intensity.  But you won't feel intimidated - there are various walkers not picking up the pace as much, not using weights, doing less intense side steps/lunges/etc. You will do some squats in Burn 30, and prepare your thighs for quite a few sets of them in the Firm section.  Also - while the exercise 'class' uses a full size studio to do this program, this and many of her videos can be done with minimal space.  If you can't do double side-steps, do single side-steps and take them deeper.  There are days when I do this with the 2x4 space at the foot of my bed with the DVD playing in my laptop.  It's all about how intense you take the steps.  I also live in an apartment with a floor that can't hide much movement, but with the carpeting and wearing shoes, too much of a racket isn't made.

The plan this DVD is structured on is for users to do 'Burn' Mon/Wed/Fri, and Firm is done Tue/Thu/Sat.  I often find I do more of the 'Burn', as I enjoy the aerobics much more, but this is a great cardio/toning combination that will surely work with a sensible eating plan.

The DVD gives you the option to play the program with music & vocals or just music - a great option once you master it, and this program (and Ultimate 5 Day) has some great music to move to.

My husband got me this for Xmas (at my request).  I usually exercise 6 days a week, trying to do 3 days of cardio and 3 days of weights.  I usually do more advanced weight lifting workouts (mostly Cathe Friedrich), but sometimes I like something a little easier.  For cardio, I usually use my elliptical and rowing machine or walk outside, but I like a little variety and have around 10 of Leslie's WATP workouts.

BURN:  This is probably the best Leslie workout I have, it goes quickly and has more moves in it than the usual four.  There was plenty of variety for me, but nothing was too complex.  There is a "music only" option, which is great for the times when I am not in the mood for Leslie's chattiness.  There is no counting of miles, but a clock does pop up when there is 10 minutes left (as it does in the FIRM workout).

FIRM:  This was a bit of a mess.  For lower body there are squats, pile squats, bridges and lunges.  She also includes all the upper body muscles, but there is more back, chest and biceps than shoulders and triceps.  My biggest problem is that she doesn't count reps, which is fine when doing squats, but NOT GOOD when doing one arm rows or lunges.  She also does one-arm rows transitioning into tricep kickbacks using the same 5 pound weight, which is crazy to use the same weight for those!  I used 15 pounds for the rows and 7 pounds for the triceps (and I counted myself to keep the reps even).  It ends with some ab work, basic crunches and a few pilates moves.

Overall, I doubt I will do the FIRM again, but I will be using the BURN, it was pretty fun.

**Menu Screen**

- Introduction to the DVD
- Burn 30 Workout (with or without music ) 30 mins
- Firm 30 Workout (with or without music) 30 mins

******Burn 30 Workout******
This consist of high-intensity aerobics. They are NOT miles. This is just a full blunt workout for 30 minutes. The major moves consist of bouncing with a fist pump in the air, jogging, the run-run-run, and a new move called 'skater' where you combine side step with a foot behind the other. You can use hand-weights if you want.

  PROS

- Clock: The clock does show up, but only when 10 minutes remain in the workout and it stays until the end. I guess there's really no need for a clock. We all know how long the workout lasts.

- Key execution movies: Leslie is excellent when executing her moves. She does not surprise you or switch legs

- Music: The music is great. It forces you to be on key becuase the beat is very catchy. When you first do it, it may not seem like the music reaches out to you, but you have to give yourself a chance to get used to it. The music makes me feel young. The last song before the cool down is THE JAM! It makes you feel like you're on this serious mission. :p

- Her Friends: All are like college-based age with one woman being Leslie's age (just guessing) and then a much older woman is in the back. I felt sorry for the older woman in the back. This workout was clearly not within her abilities. She could not keep up entirely. One other thing about them is that to Leslie's left (right side of the screen) are two women that are using weight. These women are like robots! They motivate me to push myself. There was one time I was tired of holding the weights, but when the scene switched to them still carrying it, I picked mines back up.

  CONS

- None

*******Firm 30 Workout*******
This consist if toning your arms, thighs, stomach, and butt. The first part is a warm up with some brief jogging. You get right to work with squats of wide legs and legs close together. There is A LOT of squatting and lunges. I cannot stand lunges. So, I just substitute them with more squats. You'll do some lunge stances in position and then work on the arms. She'll rotate legs, but it gets you tired quick.

I normally do not like floor work, but when it's with Leslie I'm more confident about it. One the floor, she'll start with the weights raised high over your chest and then tell you to bring your elbows out and in. Then she'll do chest raises with the weights. She'll then work hard on the stomach with the little crunches. The stretch is pretty short but involves leaning on one need with the opposite hand pointing out, and the last stretch is on your back with your arms over your head laying FLAT out.

  PROS

- Clock: By the time you get on the floor the clock will appear and remain for the last 10 minutes.

- You'll get a very good workout for the legs, especially when she gets you to lean in the lunge stance while doing the arm workout.

In this video, instructor Leslie Sansone adds a strength-training component to her usual aerobic walk.  Walk It Off in 30 Days is designed to be a "specific plan" that is used for 30 days.  Sansone suggests using the walk segment of the program on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays and the strength segment section on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays (presumably, Sundays are a rest day).

The Main Menu for this DVD reads as follows:  Introduction to the 30 Day Plan--Burn 30 Workout (Play/Play with Music Only)--Firm 30 Workout (Play/Play with Music Only).  For both workout routines, Sansone teaches live in a large, bright studio with about ten different background exercises.  Dumbbells and a mat are needed for the strength routine.  Each workout is described briefly below.

BURN

This is the cardio workout, and it is fairly typical of most of Sansone's walking routines, if perhaps a bit more upbeat overall.  Sansone and a few of the other background exercisers use 2-pound hand weights throughout.  It begins with a 5-minute warm-up, and as Sansone usually does, she introduces her basic walking moves, including the walk (actually a march), knees up, hamstring curls, side steps, tap outs, front kicks, and the addition of a cha-cha.  Some of the new moves included in this workout are transitioning from the side-to-side step into a skater (adding a small hop if desired) and a bouncing move with fist pump.  At the 25-minute mark, Sansone starts to bring the heart rate back down, and she concludes the routine with approximately 2 minutes of cool-down moves.

FIRM

The strength routine begins with an aerobic-style warm-up.  This includes Sansone's typical walking moves, plus a bit of impact with some light jogs.  Using 5-pound weights for the strength work, Sansone starts with squats, performing each move slowly and deliberately but also doing several different variations, including close stance, wide stance, plié squat, and squat with overhead press, followed by a static lunge on both sides.  Moving on to the upper body, Sansone works her way through single arm rows, one-arm tricep kick-backs, double arm rows, reverse flies, bicep curls, overhead presses, and then alternating bicep curls.  She concludes the standing work with a final set of squats.  At the 20-minute mark, Sansone transitions to the floor for chest flies and chest press.  Next comes core work, which includes an abs crunch while holding one dumbbell, additional crunch variations, a short version of the Pilates 100, and then bird-dog on hands and knees.  For a final stretch, Sansone returns to her back and stretches out flat for about 30 seconds--that's it.

Sansone has a friendly, chatty personally that will be immensely appealing to many, but others may be a bit put off, especially during the strength workout, which has frequent pauses between sets to accommodate Sansone's chatter.  However, this video definitely delivers what it promises--i.e., an option to engage in cardio and strength training on alternate days.  For those looking for an easy-to-follow program, this DVD would be ideal; the level of the workouts are easy to modify, making it appropriate for beginners to low intermediate exercisers.

I've been using Leslie's videos for about a year and a half now, and have a dozen or so that I like to cycle through.  This is one of my favorites. If you are new to exercise, this probably isn't the video you want to start with. I can do her 5 mile walks and don't start sweating until mile 3 - this one has me sweating not long after starting the walk.  There are two segments, the first is the Burn 30 workout that you do Monday, Wednesday, and Friday.  The second segment is the Firm 30 workout that you do Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday.  The Burn workout uses optional light hand weights and is fast.  Even the warm up is on the fast side, and along with the usual side steps, kicks, knee lifts and kick backs, there are skaters, "step-step-run, run, runs", tap outs, double tap outs, moving kick backs, and arms go up, down and out to the sides several times. At one point, Leslie stops doing the arm moves and walks around to talk to the walkers while everyone else keeps moving the arms.  You end with some squats before a brief cool down. There about twelve walkers, mostly women with two guys.  Most of the walkers are on the young side, with two older women near the back.  The older of the two does her darndest to keep up, but also modifies the moves as she goes, and she does not join the Firm workout.  The Firm workout uses dumb bells, and starts with a peppy few minutes of standard walking moves.  The Firm workout is all basic stuff, like squats with feet apart and together, toes turned out, rows, chest presses, lunges, etc.; there is also work on the floor for the abs and buns, along with the weights.  It ends with a full body stretch.  All in all, an excellent workout that is a great addition to my Leslie Library!  If you like Leslie, and are looking for a more challenging walk from her, this is a good one.  You can preview this DVD on YouTube from Collage Video or Anchor Bay Fitness.

The music is much improved but it is fast.  Leslie also does some new moves, bounces, skaters (side steps with a toe touch to the back) and a cha cha move. The second segment is the weight segment.  You are supposed to do this segment on T, Th, Sat.  (taking Sunday off). And after squats, you do lunges.  Killer!  Leslie also does some floor exercises with the weights as well.  That's it!
